hypothesis_content.title: Intraday Liquidity Grab & Reversion in STRESS Regimes
hypothesis_content.statement: During a STRESS regime, a rapid, high-volume price move that sweps a cluster of visible stop-loss orders (inferred via order book heatmap analysis or a >2% move in under 5 minutes) and then stalls for 15 minutes within a tight range (+/-0.3%) signals a 'liquidity grab.' This creates a timing edge for a fade trade back into the pre-sweep trading range.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Stress regimes are marked by low liquidity and predatory behavior. Large players may engineer moves to trigger clustered stop-losses, acquiring liquidity at favorable prices. Once the liquidity is harvested and the move stalls, the underlying lack of follow-through often leads to a sharp reversion, as the catalyst for the move was internal (stop-hunts) not external (new information).
entry_conditions: Price moves >2.0% within a 5-minute window on volume >150% of 20-min average
Price then consolidates for 15 minutes within a +/-0.3% band of the post-move price
The move originates from within the prior 2-hour consolidation range and extends beyond it

exit_conditions.take_profit: Price retraces 50-61.8% of the initial rapid move back towards the pre-sweep range
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Price breaks the extreme of the initial rapid move by >0.5%

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: Falsified if, after the stall, the price continues in the initial direction >70% of the time, breaking the move's extreme, indicating a genuine breakdown/breakout rather than a liquidity grab.
